item.title: Greenlanders Watching Turmoil in the United States Say No Thanks
item.description: The violence in Minneapolis and President Trump’s threats have soured Greenlanders on the United States and, unexpectedly, pushed them closer to Denmark.
item.dc:creator: Maya Tekeli and Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Juliette Pavy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest this month against President Trump for his threats to take over Greenland, in the island’s capital, Nuuk.

item.title: Southern Africa Faces Devastating Flooding During Rainy Season
item.description: More than 100 deaths have been confirmed across South Africa, Zimbabwe and Mozambique, with the rains expected to continue through February.
item.dc:creator: Zimasa Matiwane and Nazaneen Ghaffar
item.media:description: Wading through floodwater near Maputo, the capital of Mozambique, on Jan. 20.

item.title: Trump Warns Iran With Military Muscle, but Risks a Regional War
item.description: Iran’s Islamic Republic, weakened by airstrikes in June and huge popular unrest, warns that it will strike back hard if attacked by the United States. This time, Iran may mean it.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke from an explosion caused by Israeli airstrikes in Tehran in June. President Trump has shown that he likes military action to be short and limited, as it was in Iran at the time.

item.title: In Beijing, Starmer and Xi Seek a Way Around a Volatile U.S.
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain is seeking to promote economic ties for growth, offering China’s leader, Xi Jinping, a way to court one of America’s allies.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Chinese and British delegations participating in a meeting between President Xi Jinping and Prime Minister Keir Starmer in Beijing on Thursday.

item.title: Moscow Airport Sells for Half Off, a Sign of Russia’s Global Isolation
item.description: The government opened the sale to cut-rate bidding for Domodedovo Airport after it received no offers at its initial asking price of $1.7 billion.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva
item.media:description: Domodedovo Airport outside Moscow, in 2023.

item.title: Netanyahu Vows to Cut Israel’s Reliance on U.S. Military Aid
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu blamed some soldiers’ deaths in the Gaza war on a lack of ammunition caused by a pause in American weapon deliveries during President Biden’s term.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu during the funeral in Meitar, Israel, on Wednesday of a hostage, Ran Gvili, whose remains were returned to Israel from Gaza.

item.title: European Union Labels Iran’s Revolutionary Guard a Terrorist Group
item.description: The move, which comes after the killing of protesters, brings the European Union in line with the United States and Canada.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek and Koba Ryckewaert
item.media:description: A photo verified by The New York Times shows a screen grab from social media of bodies in body bags outside a morgue in Tehran after days of protests, earlier this month.

item.title: French Government To Replace Zoom and Teams With Visio, a Local Alternative
item.description: French officials will soon be expected to use new French-made video conferencing software as part of an effort to “regain digital independence,” the government said.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu of France, in Paris last year. Mr. Lecornu said that officials will now use a new video conferencing platform developed by the French government.

item.title: How His Duel With Trump Boosted Emmanuel Macron, France’s Embattled President
item.description: Dismissed as a lame duck, Emmanuel Macron has clawed back some influence after his defense of Greenland and Denmark. Will quieter domestic politics allow him to secure his legacy?
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: French President Emmanuel Macron meeting on Wednesday with Denmark’s Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen, right, and Greenland Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen.

item.title: She Couldn’t Defend Herself, but He Wasn’t Charged With Rape
item.description: A decision in China not to charge a man who fathered children with a woman with a mental illness has set off a debate about consent and the state’s push for babies.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang

item.title: Iran Killed Thousands of Protesters. Here Are Five of Their Stories.
item.description: “He went out for freedom,” said the cousin of one of those who was killed when Iranian authorities mounted a deadly crackdown on protests across the country.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Leily Nikounazar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Bijan Mostafavi and Zahra Bani-Amerian with their sons Danial and Davoud. Bijan, Zahra and Danial, pictured left in this photograph, were killed in the protests that have rocked Iran over the past month.

item.title: In Kherson, Ukraine, Every Step Outside Risks Death by Drone
item.description: Russian attacks on civilians in Kherson, in southern Ukraine, have forced important aspects of life to go underground, offering a vision of a postapocalyptic future.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Mauricio Lima
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times

item.title: The Rise and Fall of South Korean First Lady Kim Keon Hee
item.description: Kim Keon Hee is the first former presidential spouse in South Korea to be convicted on a criminal charge. Her downfall began after her husband declared martial law.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Kim Keon Hee, South Korea’s former first lady, arrived for her first hearing on corruption charges at Seoul Central District Court in September.

item.title: In Nigeria, a Catholic Bishop Tries to Tone Down the Uproar After U.S. Missile Strikes
item.description: Bishop Matthew Hassan Kukah, often called “the conscience of the nation,” has been trying to tone down the uproar after President Trump bombed a region in his diocese.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.category: US Strikes on ISIS in Nigeria (2025- )
item.media:credit: Taibat Ajiboye for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bishop Matthew Hassan Kukah leads a Roman Catholic diocese in an overwhelmingly Muslim region.

item.title: The Secret Sauce in ‘Heated Rivalry’? Canada.
item.description: The global television phenomenon is full of Canadian iconography and subsidized by Canadian taxpayers. On Thursday, it came home to celebrate.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Cole Burston
item.media:credit: Cole Burston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and Heated Rivalry actor Hudson Williams on the red carpet at a conference for the Canadian Media Producers Association in Ottawa on Thursday.

item.title: Panama Court Strikes Down Hong Kong Firm’s Canal Contract
item.description: President Trump has said he wants American control of the canal, putting the longtime ports operator, CK Hutchison, in the cross-hairs of the U.S.-China trade conflict.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has frequently said he wants the United States to retake control of the Panama Canal.

item.title: South Korean Stocks, Kospi Index Are Trading at a Record High
item.description: Spurred by government policies and the global A.I. boom, the market’s value has jumped by hundreds of billions of dollars. Individual investors have piled in.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Traders at a bank celebrating the returns of the benchmark Kospi index, which has more than doubled in the past year.

item.title: Xi’s Military Purge May Set Back His Taiwan Ambitions
item.description: By ousting his top generals, Xi Jinping has secured absolute control, but has also hollowed out the command structure preparing for possible war over Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Gen. Zhang Youxia was China’s top general until he was placed under investigation in a stunning escalation of Xi Jinping’s purge of the military elite.

item.title: Michael Beck, 65, Dies; First to Report Symptoms of ‘Havana Syndrome’
item.description: As an employee with the N.S.A., he claimed he was exposed to a direct-energy device that led to a diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease at the age of 45.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Katherine Frey/The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Michael Beck in 2017. He said he began experiencing debilitating symptoms of Havana Syndrome much earlier than many other federal employees.

item.title: Venezuelan Lawmakers Approve Sweeping Overhaul of Oil Sector
item.description: Bowing to Trump administration pressure, the new legislation improves conditions for foreign oil companies and opens the way to slash the taxes they pay.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue of a hand holding a drilling rig near Venezuela’s state oil company last year.

item.title: A Global Pop Music Melting Pot
item.description: The era of American dominance is over. Music now comes from artists everywhere listening to each other.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Bad Bunny performing in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, in November.

item.title: NATO to Hold Military Exercise Without U.S., Its Largest Member
item.description: The operation, Steadfast Dart, comes as President Trump has been accused of undermining the alliance and will be watched closely to see how well the allies manage without their most important partner.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: NATO troops during last year’s Steadfast Dart training exercise near Galati, Romania.

item.title: Canada Signs Auto Deal With South Korea, Moving Further from the U.S.
item.description: The agreement, while scarce on details, is the latest step by Prime Minister Mark Carney to reduce Canada’s reliance on trade with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Cars made by Kia Motors ready to be exported at the company’s shipping yard last year in Pyeongtaek, South Korea.

item.title: Svalbard Polar Bears Are Getting Fatter (for Now), Study Finds
item.description: Seals favored by Svalbard bears are becoming easier to hunt as ice declines, a study found. But researchers say the situation may be temporary.
item.dc:creator: Eric Niiler

item.title: Rubio Says Venezuela Will Submit Monthly Budget to White House
item.description: Democrats sharply questioned the plan, including the role of Qatar in managing an account funded by the sale of Venezuelan oil.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio testified before the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations during a hearing to examine U.S. policy towards Venezuela.

item.title: Why the NORAD Cold War Pact Between the U.S. and Canada Is News
item.description: The State Department clarified comments made by the U.S. Ambassador to Canada that NORAD would be “altered” if that country did not purchase American F-35 jets.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:description: Canada began a review of its agreement to buy F-35 fighter jets from the United States last year. The United States still wants Canada to use those jets for the common defense of North American airspace.

item.title: Plane Carrying Colombian Politicians Crashes in Area Contested by Rebels
item.description: The aircraft was carrying 15 people, and the authorities said there were no survivors.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:description: The aircraft that crashed was a Beechcraft 1900, similar to this one.

item.title: Hillary Clinton and Tucker Carlson Speak at Saudi Business Forum
item.description: The Democrat and the hard-right commentator found at least one thing to agree upon as they spoke at a conference in Riyadh.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Hillary Clinton at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago in 2024. She called the changes in Saudi Arabia “exhilarating to see.”

item.title: Canada’s New Reality
item.description: What can we learn from Canada’s pivot away from the U.S.?
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A truck stop on a trade route in Alberta.

item.title: Landslide Leaves Town in Sicily Perched on a Cliff’s Edge
item.description: “We are in a movie, in a horror film,” said a resident of Niscemi, where a widening chasm is threatening the town’s historic center.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Homes perched along a landslide slope show severe structural damage, with a car left stranded at the edge of the collapsed ground on Niscemi, Italy, on Tuesday.

item.title: South Africa Cancels Release of ‘Melania’ Documentary
item.description: The distributor, which was set to release the film on Friday, said it had canceled the theatrical premiere because of “recent developments,” but declined to specify.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: The first lady, Melania Trump, at the New York Stock Exchange on Wednesday, where she rang the opening bell.

item.title: Trump Threatens Iran With ‘Massive Armada’ and Presses a Set of Demands
item.description: U.S. and European officials say they have put three demands in front of the Iranians, including a permanent end to all enrichment of uranium.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Tyler Pager and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The USS Abraham Lincoln in 2024. The aircraft carrier group is currently stationed in striking distance of targets in Iran.

item.title: Camping on Antarctica’s Thwaites Glacier
item.description: After working and camping for a week on Thwaites Glacier, scientists were ready to start drilling into the ice, if only the weather would let them.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Iraq’s Nominee for Prime Minister Rejects Trump Threats
item.description: Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a former prime minister, was nominated to lead Iraq once again, but President Trump said he would cut U.S. support if that went ahead.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Iraq’s former prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, during an election in Baghdad, last year.

item.title: After Russian Strike Kills Five, Train Sheds Burned Cars and Carries On
item.description: One Ukrainian passenger, who escaped injury after stepping out of a carriage for a cigarette, recalled carrying a bloodied woman away from the burning train.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Evelina Riabenko
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Ukrainian Emergency Service was said to show the train that was attacked by drones in the Kharkiv region on Tuesday.

item.title: Putin, Still Harboring Assad, Welcomes New Syrian Leader to Moscow Again
item.description: This is the second time that President Vladimir V. Putin has hosted President Ahmed al-Sharaa since the fall of the Russia-backed Syrian dictator Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Grand Kremlin Palace in Moscow this month.

item.title: Missing in Kabul: The U.S. Citizen Witnesses Say Was Held by the Taliban
item.description: Taliban officials deny holding a U.S.-Afghan citizen, who witnesses and U.S. officials say was detained by Afghanistan’s intelligence services in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Adam Goldman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Mahmood Shah Habibi, right, posed for a photo with his brother, Ahmad Habibi, in Canada in 2014.

item.title: Doomsday Clock Ticks Closer Than Ever to Apocalypse
item.description: Wars, climate change, disruptive technologies and the rise of autocracy over the past year prompted scientists to set the clock at 85 seconds to midnight.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: The Doomsday Clock of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists was displayed during a news conference at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington on Friday.

item.title: Ajit Pawar, a Veteran Indian Politician, Among 5 Killed in Plane Crash
item.description: Ajit Pawar, the deputy chief minister of Maharashtra State, was on board a charter jet that crashed as it was coming in to land.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B.
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ajit Pawar, the deputy chief minister of Maharashtra, in Pune, India, in 2024.

item.title: After Naval Drills With Iran, South Africa Faces New U.S. Attacks
item.description: The exercises were the second time in six months that President Cyril Ramaphosa appeared to be blindsided by his own military regarding relations with Tehran.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Zimasa Matiwane
item.media:description: An Iranian vessel leaving Simon’s Town Naval Base in South Africa on Jan. 13 during preparations for joint drills with members of the BRICS group of emerging economies, including China, Russia and Iran.

item.title: Former French Senator Convicted of Drugging a Colleague, Intending to Assault Her
item.description: The trial took on special resonance in France, a year after a court found Dominique Pelicot and dozens of other men guilty of raping Gisèle Pelicot while she was sedated.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Joël Guerriau, a former French senator, arriving at court with his lawyers in Paris on Monday.

item.title: How Iran Crushed an Uprising
item.description: A visual investigation by The New York Times shows the breadth and ferocity of the regime’s crackdown across the country.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Spain Offers Undocumented Migrants a Legal Way to Stay
item.description: The measure, unexpectedly approved, comes as other countries are cracking down on immigration.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Venezuelan food stall in Madrid in early January. The measure passed on Tuesday will apply to undocumented migrants already living in Spain, many of whom are from Latin America.

item.title: How Computer Warfare Is Becoming Part of the Pentagon’s Arsenal
item.description: The military tested a new approach in Venezuela and during strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Sella
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The United States took power off-line in Caracas, Venezuela, to help military forces capture former President Nicolás Maduro this month.

item.title: Board of Peace Set to Hand Trump Sweeping Powers Over Gaza
item.description: A draft resolution revealed some of the plans for the new international body, which met for the first time last week amid criticism from some U.S. allies.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:description: President Trump at the Board of Peace Charter announcement at the World Economic Forum, in Davos, Switzerland, last Thursday.

item.title: Troop Casualties in Ukraine War Near 2 Million, Study Finds
item.description: The number of deaths, injuries and missing is approaching a grim milestone after nearly four years of fighting.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of a Ukrainian soldier in Uzhhorod, Ukraine, last year. The latest accounting of casualties came after talks among Russian, Ukrainian and American officials ended on Saturday on a rare positive note.

item.title: Microsoft Pledged to Save Water. In the A.I. Era, It Expects Water Use to Soar.
item.description: Driven by the artificial intelligence frenzy, Microsoft is internally projecting that water use at its data centers will more than double by 2030 from 2020, including in places that face shortages.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Karen Weise

item.title: ICE Agents Will Join Olympics Delegation in Italy. Many Italians are Angry.
item.description: The Italian government said it had requested clarification from American diplomats after D.H.S. said that ICE agents would help secure the U.S. Olympic delegation next week in northern Italy.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: Federal agents confronting protesters in Minneapolis, Minnesota, last week.

item.title: As Trump Eyes Greenland, Denmark’s Leader Is Unsure How Long U.S. Will Be an Ally
item.description: President Trump’s efforts to pry Greenland from Denmark show that “the old world order is now gone,” Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen warned in Berlin.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Danish prime minister, Mette Frederiksen, is visiting European capitals with Greenland’s leader this week, apparently seeking to shore up support for Denmark’s position in talks with the United States.

item.title: Trinidadian Families File Wrongful Death Lawsuit Over Boat Strike by U.S. Military
item.description: The case tests the Trump administration’s argument that its extrajudicial killings of people suspected of smuggling drugs at sea have been lawful.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:description: A memorial held by family members of Chad Joseph, one of two Trinidadian men whom the U.S. military apparently killed in a boat strike in the fall, in Las Cuevas, Trinidad and Tobago, in October.

item.title: Albania Created an ‘A.I. Minister’ to Curb Corruption. Then Its Developers Were Accused of Graft.
item.description: The Albanian avatar known as Diella, a public anticorruption crusader, has been described as the world’s first government minister created by artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Diella, the first government minister created by artificial intelligence, has become the face of efforts to rein in graft as Albania seeks to join the European Union.

item.title: How Trump’s Threats to Greenland Made Him a Liability for Europe’s Far Right
item.description: Europe’s nationalist leaders once saw President Trump as an ideological ally. Now, as he threatens European sovereignty, they are seeking distance — at least for the moment.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek, Koba Ryckewaert and Catherine Porter
item.media:description: President Trump leaving for the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where he made a rambling speech that underscored his disdain for Europe.

item.title: Trump Vows Higher Tariffs for South Korea Months After Trade Deal
item.description: President Trump said Seoul was not moving fast enough to implement the agreement, which calls for South Korea to invest billions in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: President Trump received gilded gifts from South Korea’s leader, Lee Jae Myung, when he visited the country in October.

item.title: UK Seeks Trade With China Without Triggering Trump’s Fury
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer hopes to boost his country’s lagging economy with a trip to Beijing. But he must carefully navigate between two superpowers.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and David Pierson
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain and Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, attending a meeting in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in 2024.

item.title: All-Night Concerts in War-Ravaged Myanmar
item.description: But the shows, which combine dance, drama and music, are also part of an effort by Myanmar’s military rulers to project a veneer of legitimacy.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Lauren DeCicca
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times

item.title: Record Debt in the World’s Richest Nations Threatens Global Growth
item.description: The cost of borrowing is already choking crucial public spending in many developing economies. Now it’s raising broader alarms.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Record-high debt in the United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan risks slowing growth and destabilizing the global economy.

item.title: Trump Briefed on Intelligence Saying Iran’s Government Is Weaker
item.description: Protests that erupted late last year shook elements of the Iranian government, according to the reports.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Pager, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A street in Tehran on Sunday. The reports signal that the Iranian government’s hold on power is at its weakest point since the shah was overthrown in the 1979 revolution.

item.title: Canada’s Marineland Whales Could Find New Homes in U.S.
item.description: Marineland, a closed aquatic park in Ontario, had threatened to euthanize its whales after the government denied an application to send them to China.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Beluga whales in November at the now-closed Arctic Cove exhibit at Marineland, in Niagara Falls, Canada.

item.title: Chinese Pandas Leave Japanese Zoo
item.description: As Japan and China feud, an animal long used in Chinese diplomacy has been summoned back home.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Visitors taking last photos of Xiao Xiao at the Ueno Zoo in Tokyo on Sunday.

item.title: NATO Chief Says Europe Is ‘Dreaming’ if It Thinks It Can Defend Itself Without U.S.
item.description: Mark Rutte, the secretary general of the alliance, told members of the European Parliament that President Trump was “doing a lot of good stuff.”
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:description: Secretary General Mark Rutte of NATO, right, at the European Parliament in Brussels on Monday.
